datafield.subfield: Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec collection of Artur Schnabel materials,
Artur Schnabel - Mary Virginia Foreman LeGarrec collection,

@alpha_character^s^@alpha_srt^schnabel^@title^Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec Collection of Artur Schnabel Materials^@href^http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.music/eadmus.mu011014^@aggregate^mu^@ead_file_name^mu011014.xml^@eadid^mu011014^

Artur Schnabel was an Austrian-born American pianist, pedagogue, and composer. Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec was Schnabel's student and confidante. The collection includes holograph manuscript and published music scores by Schnabel as well as published scores by other composers, some of which contain annotations in the hands of Schnabel, Le Garrec, and others. In addition, the collection contains correspondence; writings by both Schnabel and Le Garrec; concert programs featuring Schnabel as both pianist and composer; biographical material; press clippings, published articles, and monographs regarding Schnabel and his circle; books; photographs; and other iconography.
Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec collection of Artur Schnabel materials.

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Music Division, 2011

did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec Collection of Artur Schnabel Materials 1893-1996 (bulk circa 1920-circa 1950)
did.langmaterial: Collection material in English, German, and French
did.abstract: Artur Schnabel was an Austrian-born American pianist, pedagogue, and composer. Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec was Schnabel's student and confidante. The collection includes holograph manuscript and published music scores by Schnabel as well as published scores by other composers, some of which contain annotations in the hands of Schnabel, Le Garrec, and others. In addition, the collection contains correspondence; writings by both Schnabel and Le Garrec; concert programs featuring Schnabel as both pianist and composer; biographical material; press clippings, published articles, and monographs regarding Schnabel and his circle; books; photographs; and other iconography.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

controlaccess.head: People
controlaccess.persname: Schnabel, Artur, 1882-1951. Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec collection of Artur Schnabel materials. 1893-1996.

controlaccess.head: Titles
controlaccess.title: Artur Schnabel - Mary Virginia Foreman LeGarrec collection, 1893-1996

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Gift; Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec; 1997.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec Collection of Artur Schnabel Materials was processed by Kevin LaVine in 2006. The finding aid was coded for EAD format by Nancy Seeger in 2011.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: One acetate disc of Schnabel speaking, recorded at HMV Studios in London on June 6, 1950, was transferred to the Library of Congress Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division in March 2001.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The Library of Congress Music Division also holds the Artur Schnabel Collection which primarily consists of music manuscript scores of Schnabel’s compositions. The manuscripts are all, with the exception of a single copyist’s score, in Schnabel’s hand, and represent his compositional essays in a variety of genres, from solo song (voice and piano) to symphonic works. The collection also contains an early published edition of Ludwig van Beethoven’s sonatas for solo piano, containing copious annotations in Schnabel’s hand, and on which he apparently based his 1935 edition of these works.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec Collection of Artur Schnabel Materials is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.) and other applicable international copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec Collection of Artur Schnabel Materials is open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Music Division prior to visiting in order to determine whether the desired materials will be available at that time.
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec Collection of Artur Schnabel Materials, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Artur Schnabel was one of the greatest pianists and pedagogues in the history of musical performance. As a performer, Schnabel eschewed virtuosity in favor of musicianship – indeed, he considered himself a musician foremost, and the piano simply his creative medium – and his sound recordings consistently demonstrate interpretations of sensitivity, commitment, and distinction. He was one of the first pianists to champion new and unfamiliar repertoire (such as the piano sonatas of Franz Schubert), and the first pianist to record the complete sonatas and concerti of Ludwig van Beethoven. As a pedagogue, Schnabel is probably best known for his meticulously annotated performing edition of Beethoven’s piano sonatas, through which countless pianists were introduced to these foundations of the piano repertoire; this edition is in common use even today. Lesser known are Schnabel’s original musical compositions – his uncompromising atonal musical language continues to pose formidable challenges to performers, conductors and listeners – and his contribution to musical scholarship through his autobiography (My Life and Music, 1961), his two books on the role of music in the twentieth century (Reflections on Music, 1934 and Music and the Line of Most Resistance, 1942), and through the several articles he contributed to musical journals throughout his life.

Schnabel’s student and confidante, Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec (born 1908), donated her collection of correspondence, musical scores, writings, concert programs, press clippings, publications, photographs, and other memorabilia related to Schnabel, to the Library in 1997.

chronitem.event: Artur Schnabel born, Lipnik, Carpathia, Austria
Began piano studies with Hans Schmitt
Gave first public concert in Vienna
Began piano studies with Leschetitzky in Vienna
Won prizes for three of his works for solo piano in composition competition organized by Leschetitzky
Graduated from Leschetitzky’s class; received first prize

eventgrp.event: Moved to Berlin to begin his professional career
Met contralto Therese Behr (b. 1876), a “lieder singer of repute”

chronitem.event: Married Therese Behr (died 1959), they gave intermittent concerts together for the next twenty-five years, performing together primarily throughout Germany and Scandinavia
Mary Virginia Foreman born, Minneapolis, Minnesota
Schnabel made first recital tour of United States
Schnabel made second recital tour of United States
Schnabel became professor, piano, Berlin Hochschule für Musik
Schnabel performed in recital series with violinist Carl Flesch
Schnabel performed Beethoven’s thirty-two piano sonatas in one season in Berlin, in celebration of the centenary of the composer’s birth
Schnabel recorded Beethoven's thirty-two piano sonatas and five piano concerti for the British firm HMV

eventgrp.event: Schnabel and Foreman met, Minneapolis (Schnabel was visiting studio of Foreman's piano teacher)
Schnabel was guest soloist with the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra (Eugene Ormandy conducted)
Schnabel performed Beethoven’s Concerto no. 3, op. 37, at the University of Minnesota’s Cyrus Northrup Memorial Hall
Foreman attended concert with her mother (at Schnabel’s insistence, Foreman remained backstage with Schnabel for the concert’s second half, after having delivered sandwiches to him)

chronitem.event: Schnabel left Germany and settled in Lake Como, Italy, where he lived for the remainder of his life
Foreman moved to New York City after accepting parents' offer to study piano for one year with Edwin Hughes (she resided at the Three Arts Club at 340 West 85th Street)
Schnabel published Reflections on Music. New York: Simon and Schuster

eventgrp.event: Schnabel performed at Carnegie Hall in New York
Schnabel and Foreman were reacquainted after the concert; Schnabel recognized her from earlier meeting in Minneapolis

chronitem.event: Foreman began a correspondence with Schnabel which would last until his death in 1951
Schnabel published his edition of complete piano sonatas of Ludwig van Beethoven, in two volumes (over 800 pages). New York: Simon and Schuster
Schnabel performed thirty-two sonatas of Beethoven on “7 Wednesday nights in Carnegie Hall”
Schnabel became professor, University of Michigan
Schnabel published Music and the Line of Most Resistance. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press (his thoughts on music and musical esthetics)
Schnabel became a naturalized American citizen
Schnabel returned to home in Lake Como, Italy

eventgrp.event: Première performance of Symphony no. 1, by Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Dimitri Mitropoulos (this difficult and atonal work would be the only one of Schnabel's four symphonies to be performed during his lifetime)
Schnabel appeared as soloist in Beethoven’s Concerto no. 4 in the same concert

chronitem.event: Schnabel suffered near-fatal heart attack that left him bedridden for nearly four months

Schnabel's last performance, at Hunter College, New York (of the occasion he wrote, “For the first time I succeeded today in playing the last line of Beethoven’s opus 90 [Sonata] so that I found it convincing”)
Schnabel died, Grand Hotel in Axenstein, Switzerland
Foreman met Yves Le Garrec (born 1890, La Rochelle, France) in Paris
Foreman married Yves Le Garrec (after a period of traveling throughout Europe, they settle in Biarritz, France)
Yves Le Garrec died in Biarritz

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec Collection of Artur Schnabel Materials consists of material donated to the Library in 1997 by Le Garrec, who was Schnabel's student and confidante. The collection includes published music scores by Schnabel as well as by other composers, some of which contain annotations and performance indications in the hands of Schnabel, Le Garrec, and others. In addition, the collection contains Schnabel's correspondence with music figures such as Clifford Curzon, Rudolf Firkušný and Le Garrec; and Le Garrec’s correspondence with, among others, Pierre Fournier, René Liebowitz, Leopold Mannes, and Dmitri Mitropoulos. The collection also includes writings by both Schnabel and Le Garrec; concert programs featuring Schnabel as both pianist and composer; biographical material; press clippings, published articles, and monographs regarding Schnabel and his circle; books; photographs; and other iconography.

arrangement.head: Organization of the Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec Collection of Artur Schnabel Materials
arrangement.p: The Mary Virginia Foreman Le Garrec Collection of Artur Schnabel Materials is organized in eight series:

item.ref: Press Clippings, Published Articles, and Monographs, circa 1920-circa 1990

did.unittitle: Music Scores, 1893-1986, undated
Holograph Manuscript Scores of Works by Schnabel, 1944-1948, undated
One copy of the inventory/finding aid of the contents of this collection
Dance and secret, for chorus and orchestra, undated

physdesc.extent: Holograph manuscript full score, in pencil; 1, 42 numbered pages (22 leaves)

note.p: Includes three (3) leaves (5 pages) of text in the hand of MVFLG that contains her personal commentary about, and performance history of, this work. The text also includes her commentary about Schnabel’s Joy and Peace and Symphony no. 1 as well as transcriptions from Schnabel’s correspondence regarding Dance and Secret.
Includes photocopies of texts.

did.unittitle: Dance and secret, for chorus and orchestra, August 28, 1944

physdesc.extent: Holograph manuscript condensed score, in pencil and ink; 14 leaves

note.p: Noted at end: “ Gaston Ranch.”
Contains five (5) pages of photocopies of information about this work and transcriptions (in the hand of MVFLG) from Schnabel’s correspondence about this work.
The original copies of these five pages, in MVFLG’s hand, are held in Box 1/Folder 2.

did.unittitle: Joy and peace, for chorus and orchestra, undated

physdesc.extent: Holograph manuscript full score, in pencil; 1, 34 numbered pages (18 leaves)

note.p: Contains one photocopied page of information about this work, in the hand of MVFLG, the original of which is held in Box 1/Folder 2.

did.unittitle: Joy and peace, for chorus and orchestra, September 14, 1944

physdesc.extent: Holograph manuscript condensed score, in pencil; 9 leaves

note.p: Contains one photocopied page of information about this work, in the hand of MVFLG, the original of which is held in Box 1/Folder 2.

did.unittitle: Rhapsody, for orchestra, November 14, 1946

physdesc.extent: Holograph manuscript full score, in pencil with emendations in red, blue and green pencil; 53 numbered pages/leaves

did.unittitle: Rhapsody, for orchestra, July 31, 1946

physdesc.extent: Holograph manuscript condensed score, in pencil; 2, 14 numbered pages (16 leaves)

note.p: Introductory page 2 contains transcriptions (in the hand of MVFLG, in ink, recto and verso of the page) from the correspondence of Schnabel regarding this work.

did.unittitle: Trio, for violin, violoncello, and piano, September 7, 1945

physdesc.extent: Holograph manuscript score, in pencil; 2, 20 pages (21 leaves)

note.p: Noted at end: “ Moosehead Lake.”

did.unittitle: Waltz, for piano solo, April 28, 1948

physdesc.extent: Holograph manuscript score, in pencil; 1 page

note.p: Contains extensive text annotations throughout (suggested English lyrics to the melody of this work?), in pencil and ink, by MVFLG.

did.unittitle: Unidentified sketch, undated

physdesc.extent: Varies between one and four staves; in pencil and red pencil; 2 pages (one leaf)

note.p: Labeled at top of page, in ink, in the hand of MVFLG, “Work sheet of Artur Schnabel / Paul Zukofsky found interesting - M.V.F.”

did.unittitle: Published and Photoreproduced Scores of Works by Schnabel, 1904-1986, undated

[Sketch, unidentified.] Varies between one and four staves; in pencil and red pencil; undated; 2 pages (one leaf). Labeled at top of page, in ink, in the hand of MVFLG, “Work sheet of Artur Schnabel / Paul Zukofsky found interesting - M.V.F.”
Abendlandschaft, op. 14, no. 4, for voice and piano; German lyrics by Joseph von Eichendorff. Berlin: Verlag Dreililien, 1904

note.p: Contains annotations (photocopied from original) in the hand of MVFLG for English and French translations of the song’s original lyrics.

did.unittitle: Dance and secret; Joy and peace, for chorus and orchestra, undated

physdesc.extent: Full score, reproduced from copyist’s manuscript, plastic spiral bound; 45 p.

note.p: Contains performance indications throughout, in blue pencil.

did.unittitle: Dann, op. 11, no. 2 [from Zehn Lieder], for voice and piano; German lyrics by Richard Dehmel, undated

physdesc.extent: Photoreproduction of unidentified published score; 2 p.

note.p: Contains original annotations, in ink, in the hand of MVFLG for an English translation of the song’s original lyrics.

did.unittitle: Dieses ist ein rechter Morgen, op. 11, no. 5 [from Zehn Lieder], for voice and piano; German lyrics by Stefan George. Berlin: Verlag Dreililien, undated

note.p: The score carries annotations throughout, including an English language version of the song’s lyrics, in black and blue ink, in the hand of MVFLG.

did.unittitle: Notturno, for voice and piano; German lyrics (lyricist not identified). Ship Bottom, New Jersey: APNM (Association for the Promotion of New Music), 1986

note.p: Verso of cover page, verso of end page, and page one carry annotations regarding this work, in black ink, in the hand of MVFLG. Performance indications, in pencil and in black ink, appear throughout.

note.p: Contains extensive performance indications throughout, in pencil, in Schnabel’s hand.

Cover page carries annotations, in black and blue inks, in the hand of MVFLG: Schnabel’s Berlin address (“Charlottenberg, Wielandstrasse 14”); and “His [Schnabel’s] personal copy from 1890's - The first he played - M.V.F.”
In extremely fragile condition.

note.p: Contains performance indications, in pencil, in Schnabel’s hand (according to annotation on page 35 – the de facto cover page – in blue and black ink, in the hand of MVFLG: “All marks by A. Schnabel.”).
In fragile condition.

note.p: Contains extensive performance indications throughout, in pencil and blue inks, in the hands of Schnabel and MVFLG.
In extremely fragile condition.

did.unittitle: Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus. Sonatas, K. 381, 358, 497, 521; Fantasias, K. 594, 608; Variationen, K. 501; Fuge, K. 401. [Original-Kompositionen. Klavier zu 4 Händen], for piano four hands. Edited by Adolf Ruthardt. Leipzig: C.F. Peters, undated

note.p: Contains performance indications throughout, in pencil, in Schnabel's hand (according to an annotation on the score’s cover, in black ink, in the hand of MVFLG: “Markings by Artur Schnabel.”).
In fragile condition.

did.unittitle: Schubert, Franz. Fantaisie, op. 103; Grand Rondeau, op. 107; Deux Marches caractéristiques, op. 121; Rondeau, op. 138; Grand duo, op. 140; Allegro, op. 144; Fugue, op. 152 [Original-Kompositionen. Klavier zu 4 Händen. Band III], for piano four hands. Leipzig: C.F. Peters, undated

note.p: Contains performance indications throughout in the hands of Schnabel (in pencil) and of MVFLG (in pencil and in black ink).
In fragile condition.

did.unittitle: Schubert, Franz. Fantaisie, op. 159, for violin and piano. Braunschweig: Henry Litolff, undated

note.p: Contains performance indications, in pencil, in the hands of Schnabel and of MVFLG.

did.unittitle: Schubert, Franz. Impromptus, op. 90 [D. 899], 142 [D. 935]; Moments musicaux, op. 94 [D. 780], for piano solo. Boston: B.F. Wood Music Corp., undated

note.p: Indication on cover, in black ink, in the hand of MVFLG: “All markings by hand by Artur Schnabel...,” although markings that appear throughout the score, in pencil, appear to be in the hands of both Schnabel and MVFLG.
In extremely fragile condition.

did.unittitle: Schubert, Franz. Sonatas, op. 78 [D. 894], 164 [D. 537], and three posthumous opuses [D. 958, 959, 960] [Sonatas for Piano, Part II], for piano solo. New York: Edwin F. Kalmus, undated

note.p: Contains performance indications, in pencil and in blue ink, in the hands of both Schnabel and MVFLG.

did.unittitle: Schumann, Robert. Arabeske, op. 18, for piano solo. Edited by Max Vogrich. New York: G. Schirmer, Inc., 1893; reprint 1924

note.p: Contains performance indications throughout, in pencil, in Schnabel’s hand.
End cover page carries an inscription, in pencil, in the hand of MVFLG: “Eusebius Mandyczewski - A.S.’s composition teacher.”

did.unittitle: Schumann, Robert. Davidsbündler, op. 6, for piano solo. Leipzig: Breitkopf & Härtel, undated (“First edition”)

note.p: Contains performance indications throughout, in pencil and in black ink.

did.unittitle: Schumann, Robert. Kinderscenen, op. 15, for piano solo. Boston: B.F. Wood Music Co., undated

note.p: According to notes on the cover and title pages, in black ink, in the hand of MVFLG, performance indications in this score were made by Schnabel and by Clyde Stephens, MVFLG’s teacher while attending the University of Minnesota.
The score also contains performance indications, in pencil, in the hand of MVFLG.

did.unittitle: Schumann, Robert. Phantasie, op. 17, for piano solo. Leipzig: Breitkopf & Härtel, undated

note.p: Contains performance indications, in pencil, that were made (according to an annotation on the score’s cover page, in black ink, in the hand of MVFLG) by “Leonard Shure [,] assistant of A. Schnabel.”

did.unittitle: Schumann, Robert. Variations on the name “Abegg,” op. 1; Papillons, op. 2, for piano solo. Edited by Max Vogrich (Schirmer’s Library of Musical Classics, v. 23). New York: G. Schirmer, Inc., 1914

note.p: Contains performance indications throughout, in pencil, in Schnabel’s hand.

did.unittitle: Facsimile Editions, 1921-1923, undated
Beethoven, Ludwig van. Sonata, op. 57, “Appassionata,” for piano solo. Paris: Editions d’Art H. Piazza, undated

physdesc.extent: Facsimile edition of holograph manuscript; 45 p. (numbered copy 475 of 500 printed editions)

note.p: Notation on verso of cover indicates that Schnabel gave this score to MVFLG.

Includes a concert program affixed to the verso of the cover from the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, program of 20 and 21 February 1936, carries annotations, in pencil and in ink, in the hand of MVFLG, indicating that this particular concert marked “[Rudolf] Serkin’s début in U.S.A.”
Photoreproduced letter of “Baillot fils,” in French, affixed to verso of cover.

did.unittitle: Beethoven, Ludwig van. Sonata, op. 78 [Klaviersonate, Fis-dur], for piano solo. München: Drei Masken Verlag, 1923

physdesc.extent: Facsimile edition of holograph manuscript; 17 p.

note.p: Notation on verso of cover indicates that Schnabel gave this score to MVFLG.

did.unittitle: Beethoven, Ludwig van. Sonata, op. 111 [Klaviersonate, C-moll], for piano solo. München: Drei Masken Verlag, 1922

physdesc.extent: Facsimile edition of holograph manuscript; 41 p.

note.p: Notation on verso of cover indicates that Schnabel gave this score to MVFLG.

did.unittitle: Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus. Trio, K. 542 [Klavier-Trios, E-dur], for violin, violoncello, and piano. München: Drei Masken Verlag, 1921

physdesc.extent: Facsimile edition of holograph manuscript; 27 p.

note.p: Notation on verso of cover indicates that this score was given by Schnabel to MVFLG.

physdesc.extent: In blue and black inks; 1 p.

physdesc.extent: Original typescript, in black ink; 11 p.

note.p: Contains holograph annotations (“Part One”).

physdesc.extent: Typescript (original and carbon copies), in black ink; 12 p.

note.p: Contains holograph annotations (“Part Two”).

“Impressions of the Edinburgh Festival,” undated

note.p: Published article from unidentified publication (Edinburgh Festival program?).

physdesc.extent: Typescript (carbon copies), 11, 7, 8 p.; original typescript, 12, 8, 8 p.

note.p: Emendations appear throughout in the hand of MVFLG; a small note in her hand is also included.

note.p: Published article (newspaper clipping) from the New York Times.

note.p: Published article from the Saturday Review of Literature.

Artur Schnabel remembered, 1961, 1996

note.p: Contains emendations in blue and black inks in the hand of MVFLG. The original typescript is dated 1961; a handwritten note (in black ink, in the hand of MVFLG) dated 1996, was subsequently added to the typescript.

History of a Love Affair, May 1993, Biarritz, France

physdesc.extent: Bound notebook in 68 numbered pages; in black ink

note.p: Entirely in MVFLG’s hand.

unittitle.bibref: Da Ponte, Lorenzo. Music by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. Don Giovanni (Don Juan). A Grand opera in two acts. New York: Fred Rullman, Inc., n.d.

note.p: Libretto in Italian and English.

unittitle.bibref: Dent, Edward J., Eric Blom, and Clemence Dane. Mozart’s “Così fan tutte.” London: The Governors of Sadler’s Wells Foundation/John Lane the Bodley Head, 1946
Saerchinger, César. Introduction by Clifford Curzon. Artur Schnabel: a biography. London: Cassell & Company Ltd., 1957

note.p: Contains annotations throughout, in pencil and in blue, black, and green inks, in the hand of MVFLG.

unittitle.bibref: Schnabel, Artur. Music and the line of most resistance. Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1942

note.p: Verso of title page carries a dedication in Schnabel’s hand: “To M.V., / recommending the two lines: good / music and strong resistance – / for productive cooperation. / A.S. / N.Y.C. January 29, 1942”. Contains annotations throughout, in pencil, in the hand of MVFLG.

unittitle.bibref: Schnabel, Artur. Edited and with an introduction by Edward Crankshaw. My life and music. New York: St. Martin’s Press, 1961

note.p: Contains annotations throughout, in pencil and in black ink, and one inlaid note, in black ink, in the hand of MVFLG.

unittitle.bibref: Schnabel, Artur. Reflections on music. New York: Simon and Schuster, 1934

note.p: Title page carries a dedication in Schnabel’s hand: “To Mary Virginia / A.S. / February 1935”.

unittitle.bibref: Shakespeare, William. Edited by W.J. Craig. The complete works of Shakespeare. New York: Oxford University Press, n.d.

note.p: Carries a dedication in Schnabel’s hand: “A.S. / 17.IV.1936 / Many happy returns!!!” Enclosed note, in blue ink, in the hand of MVFLG, reads: “This book was / given me by A.S. / on his birthday. / He was leaving / for Europe! / M.V.F.”

unittitle.bibref: Turner, W.J. Blow for balloons : being the first hemisphere of the history of Henry Airbubble. London: J.M. Dent & Sons Ltd., 1935
Turner, W.J. Henry Airbubble: in search of a circumference to his breath; being the second hemisphere of the history of Henry Airbubble. London: J.M. Dent & Sons Ltd., 1936

note.p: Contains annotations on inside cover page, in black ink, in the hand of MVFLG.

unittitle.bibref: Wolff, Konrad. The teaching of Artur Schnabel: a guide to interpretation. London: Faber and Faber, 1972
